properties.description: A fire engine en route to a fire got stuck behind a stationary Recology garbage truck. A Cruise driverless car going in the opposite direction stopped right next to the garbage truck, making it impossible to drive around. The fire engine was "dead in the water" until Recology workers moved their truck.

Enroute to a fire under the freeway on Cesar Chavez, firefighters encountered a "potentially unsafe situation with a Cruise driverless car" at an intersection. The car reportedly drove through a stop sign in the direction of the fire engine.
Firefighters were battling a fire when a driverless car going west drove over their fire hoses at 10 to 15 miles per hour. The reporting firefighter called its driving "hazardous."

At an active fire, a driverless car moved toward the scene and "was going to run over our hoses," wrote the reporting firefighter. He yelled at the car to stop, banged his fist on the hood and, when the car kept coming, he smashed its window.

A crew was fighting a fire on the sidewalk. A Cruise car drove between the firefighters and their engine, and "stopped on top of our hoseline." A firefighter spoke to a Cruise operator through the car intercom and, after five minutes, the car moved away.
A fire truck returning from a call was blocked by "two autonomous Cruise vehicles blocking the road." The reporting firefighter said that the cars did not respond to the fire engine's truck or horn.

While driving westbound on Palou Ave., a driverless Waymo car turned into the firefighters' path and refused to move for about a minute. The firefighter knocked on the car's window to notify Waymo about the error but purportedly was not answered.

A Waymo driverless car allegedly turned "sharply" and accelerated toward the firefighters' vehicle after being overtaken. "I accelerated to avoid being hit by the driverless vehicle," the reporting firefighter wrote.

A firefighting crew was responding to a tree that had fallen on a vehicle. Two Waymo driverless cars came toward the firefighters at pace and "slowed down last minute." The reporting firefighter said the cars put his crew at risk.

While clearing up downed trees, two Cruise driverless cars drove through the firefighters' caution tape. They plowed into fallen Muni electrical wires, which got tangled in their roof cameras. Firefighters "took manual control of the vehicles."

A driverless Cruise car reportedly stopped less than a few feet from a fire engine attending an incident. After several minutes it was remotely moved, turned briefly into an oncoming lane, then corrected itself and drove away.
Firefighters were conducting a "hose line drill" outside the fire station. A driverless car drove past safety cones and right into the hose's stream, then pulled over and activated its hazard lights.
A fire engine was blocked from getting close to a reported fire by a Cruise driverless car. The car "created an obstacle for water supply." The fire was ultimately a false alarm.

Firefighters were battling a fire when a Cruise car drove up to the scene, "approximately ten feet" from their fire engine. The firefighters "attempted to disable the vehicle" and it drove away ten minutes later "of its own accord."

While firefighters were battling a fire, a Cruise driverless car slowly moved toward one of their fire engines. A firefighter placed "chalk blocks" in front of the car to stop it jeopardizing their water supply. After 10 minutes on the phone to a Cruise representative, the car backed away.
A Waymo driverless car blocked a fire truck en route to an incident. The firefighters spoke to a remote operator via the car's intercom. The operator agreed to move but the car remained stationary.
En route to a building alarm, a Cruise car was blocking traffic and "lurching forward in uneven movements." The reporting firefighter said that the car "came too close" to their fire engine.

A Cruise driverless car stopped "approximately 6 feet" from a fire engine responding to an incident. The car came "close to compromising a hose lead." Firefighters began "poking and prodding the vehicle, and pounding on the windows." A remote operator ultimately drove the car away.

When firefighters responded to a building alarm, a Cruise driverless car "attempted to squeeze past" two fire engines. "As these autonomous vehicles are learning traffic patterns they have become more aggressive with first responder units and their attempts to navigate around them," wrote the reporting firefighter.

Firefighters found an intoxicated passenger in the back of a Waymo driverless car. When he left the vehicle, the firefighters asked a remote Waymo rep if they could move the car to stop it blocking the road. The rep said a technician was required to move the car.
A Waymo driverless car reportedly "suddenly stopped" in front of a fire department vehicle while it was trying to enter the fire station.

A driverless vehicle reportedly blocked a fire engine in the station when it was called to an incident. Firefighters attempted to move the car unsuccessfully. Fortunately the incident turned out to be a false alarm.

After responding to a building alarm, a Cruise driverless car reportedly pulled up directly behind a fire engine. After 20 minutes it allegedly pulled into another lane, "narrowly missing a firefighter" before driving away.

A driverless Waymo car reportedly blocked a fire truck as it was backing into the fire station. Firefighters tried to speak remotely to a Waymo employee through the car, and it tried to roll up its windows.

A Cruise driverless car reportedly "ran over several lengths of hose" and other equipment in the street, only stopping when approached by firefighters. Firefighters noted that this caused "several thousand dollars of damage."
Three Cruise driverless cars reportedly caused traffic to back up in front of the fire station when they refused to drive through green lights.

A stopped Cruise driverless car forced firefighters to "maneuver around in heavy traffic to obtain apparatus placement." "I recommend these companies work to ensure the vehicles pull over appropriately and not stop their vehicles in the middle of intersections," wrote the reporting firefighter.
A driverless Waymo car was parked in the way when firefighters were responding to a building alarm. It reportedly took 6 minutes for the vehicle "to move out of the way of the incident."

A driverless Cruise car reportedly "creeped" toward a fire truck while firefighters were putting away equipment. The car stopped three feet away and the reporting firefighter said they "felt the members were not safe to put away their equipment."
A driverless Waymo with a passenger in the back reportedly blocked a fire truck in the station while it was trying to answer a call at 766 Vallejo St. The car moved after 2-3 minutes.

A driverless Waymo car parked in front of a fire station, blocking the engine bay while firefighters tried to respond to a medical call at 491 Chestnut St. It reportedly took 8 minutes for a Waymo employee to manually override the car and drive away.

A fire truck drove through a red light to reach a building alarm, moving at around 10 miles per hour. A Cruise driverless car reportedly did not slow until it was in the intersection and stopped "a few feet" from the truck.

Two fire department vehicles were double parked while responding to a building alarm. Two Cruise driverless cars tried to pass in different directions and briefly blocked one another. If more trucks had been required, the firefighter wrote, "the open lane would have been rendered useless."

Drivers were being redirected around a vehicle collision. A police officer was directing a fire truck as it reversed toward the scene. At the same time, drivers were being redirected around the accident, but a Cruise driverless car "failed to yield." The officer jumped out of the car's way and the fire truck struck a parked car.

Firefighters were responding to an incident on Freeway 280, and a driverless car stopped. "A car that comes to a stop on the freeway poses a great hazard to oncoming traffic," wrote the reporting firefighter.

Firefighters were dispatched to a medical incident. A Waymo driverless car blocked a road to the scene, so the fire department vehicle had to back up and use an alternate route. This caused an approximately four minute delay.
Firefighters were responding to a building alarm when a Cruise vehicle "frozen on the corner… slightly slowed our response." There was a driver in the Cruise car at the time.

After a fire, a driverless Cruise car reportedly "blocked in" a fire engine. Nearby Cruise employees were unable to immediately move the car. It ultimately moved on its own and released the fire engine.
A Waymo driverless car twice attempted to maneuver around firefighters who were stopping traffic while a fire truck backed into the station.
A Waymo car reportedly blocked a one-way street during an incident. It allegedly took 10 minutes for the road to be cleared.

A Waymo driverless car reportedly blocked the route of a fire engine returning to the station. Another incident occurred while the fire engine was blocked; it reversed to find another way around. "The Waymo vehicle had no reaction to being on a tight street... but to stop and be a barrier that would not move," wrote the reporting firefighter.

A Waymo driverless car was en route to run over a hose line during a fire. A firefighter stopped the car by standing in front of it and putting a chalk block under its tire. The car drove over the tire, made a U-turn, and drove away.
A Waymo vehicle reportedly "lunged forward" while a fire truck was reversing into the station, "nearly striking" a firefighter blocking traffic in the street.

Firefighters responded to a fire in a "fully occupied apartment building." A Cruise driverless car reportedly blocked "the two possible aerial ladder placements" available to the fire truck. The fire truck waited 30 seconds for the car to move, but it remained still, so it moved to the other side of the street to fight the fire from there.

After responding to a building alarm, firefighters were backing a fire truck into the station. A Cruise driverless car "narrowly missed" a firefighter stopping traffic. "This could have been a major tragedy if the spotter was distracted," wrote the reporting firefighter.

A Cruise driverless car reportedly blocked fire department vehicles from arriving at a police scene "a few hundred feet away." It allegedly failed to turn around and did not respond to efforts to stop it. It ultimately pulled in parallel to a driveway.
A Cruise driverless car reportedly blocked at intersection while firefighters responded to an incident. The blockage lasted for about five minutes.
A Cruise driverless car "slightly delayed" firefighters' response to a fire, as it was briefly in the way of the engine seeking to "facilitate a supply line."
Firefighters performing morning checks on their truck were approached by a Cruise driverless car. The firefighters put a cone on the car to disable it until someone came to manually remove it.
A firefighter working a blaze reported a Cruise vehicle stopping “right next to” their engine and staying there for “approximately 30 minutes.”

En route to a medical call, a driverless Cruise car reportedly stopped in the middle of the road. "There was plenty of room to move out of the way, but it just stopped," wrote the reporting firefighter.
While reversing in a fire engine, a Cruise driverless car stopped in a crosswalk, "resulting in a delay." "The Cruise Vehicle never cleared the crosswalk for us," wrote the reporting firefighter.

At the Legion of Honor, a Waymo driverless car parked itself between a fire truck and a burning car. “This action impacted our suppression efforts negatively due to members having to walk around the Waymo with a charged hose line and fight active fire,” wrote the reporting firefighter.

Following a traffic collision, firefighters were rendering aid to a police officer and a civilian. A Cruise driverless car "attempted to drive through the scene." The police shut off the emergency lights on their vehicles in an attempt to get the car to leave.
properties.location: Cesar Chavez St. and Kansas St.

properties.description: Fire department vehicles responded to a building alarm. A Cruise driverless car pulled up behind a fire engine and stopped. The vehicle reportedly "kept reversing backward and then moving forward" during the incident, preventing firefighters from positioning equipment "in the appropriate position."
